utterances: Pace and his deputies patrol this and other inundated parts of town, making sure looters stay out.

Boykin has at least five more agonizing days ahead of her.

So what the secretary of state, what the president decide is much more important because they send the instructions to the U.S.
representative.
That said, ambassadors can make a difference.
A lot is negotiated late at night at the U.N.
And the willingness of the ambassador to make some compromises, then his or her ability to sell those compromises back in Washington can count for something.
So maybe it's five or 10 percent of the ultimate policy, but a lot of history happens in the range of a five or 10 percent.

Ah the Cannes Film Festival, important filmmakers discussing groundbreaking movies about the issues of the day, high-stakes international business deals and a giant inflatable cartoon character strutting down the red carpet.
Cannes is where every May, France celebrates all things cinematic.
From the ridiculous to the sublime, and, okay, we usually do pay a lot more attention to the ridiculous.
Charles Ealy is navigating those treacherous waters again this year.
He's the movie editor of the Austin American Statesman, and he's on the line with us from the South of France.
Charles, thank you so much for letting us tear you away from that incredibly difficult assignment.
Thank you.
I understand you had a pretty interesting lunch today.
Yes, I did.

I went to lunch with director Ang Lee and the cast members of his new movie, ""Taking Woodstock."" It's a behind-the-scenes look at the Woodstock festival and how it came about, and it deals with a son who lives with his crazy parents in a run-down motel in the Catskills and concocts a plan to get the Woodstock festival there, and then they get besieged by the hundred-thousand of people who want to be at the concert.
What did Ang Lee have to say about making the movie?

He said it was the first movie he really enjoyed making in a long time simply because it was a comedy, and he had been doing dramas and serious things for 13 years, and he wanted to be able to laugh while he was making a movie.
They had to have lots of extras, especially for the nude scenes.
He needed somebody who looked like hippies, and when they take off their clothes, he needed pubic hair, and a lot of people shave that these days.
So he said it was hard finding extras.
How's the movie, I mean, in addition to hairy?
(Soundbite of laughter)
It's getting mixed reviews, but I liked it.
I thought it was a very gentle and fun look at that period of time.
There has been a lot of coverage about the opening night film from the Disney Pixar folks.
It's called ""Up."" How did it go over?
It went over well.
Typically, such movies that open the festivals do not go well, but it was very warmly received on La Croisette, and there were balloons everywhere after the screening.
They gave out helium-filled balloons to everyone on the streets, and it was - the critics loved it.
I thought the French might hate it, but they didn't.
The basic plot is a man who levitates its house with a whole huge bunch of helium balloons and goes on a little trip?

Well, it's a really big trip, to South America, and there is a little stowaway on board, a kid, who's about eight years old, and the ole man and the kid sort of bond over their adventure, and he becomes reconnected with the world.
So how many movies have you seen so far?
Probably about 15.
Anything really stand out?
Yes.
The one I saw tonight.
I felt, as I was leaving the theater, that I had just witnessed a moment in cinematic history.
It was called ""Antichrist."" It's the new movie from Lars von Trier.
It has some of the most emotionally violent scenes I've ever watched.
The violence is happening to somebody you care about, and that's what makes it more shocking than some kind of gore-porn like ""Hostel"" or something like that.
There are two movies that haven't screened yet that have gotten a lot of advanced buzz.
One is the new movie from Quentin Tarantino.
It's a historical war movie called ""Inglourious Basterds.
Let's play a clip.
